translation.line: (1) Year 17, 5 days of the month of Skarhvāra, of the king of Khotan Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ.

At that time this writ (was made) (2) for the following reason: Sīḍaka is getting a man for *official work together with water and ground. However many years accordingly they request any *official matter (3) in the future, Sīḍaka provides it, (whether) much (or) little—as much as they request. And whatever (4) old ṣaṃgas (of grain are) owed—Brīyāsa and Budarśaṃʾ keeps the account of them. Sīḍaka has no dispute there.

(5) And now Brīyāsa has delivered grain to the Chinese himself. And when—the grain at the top of the year—Sīḍaka delivers that, (6) and (= then) Brīyāsa will himself bring *that much. And whatever clothing goes to (= is sent to?) him, that Sīḍaka does for him, and (7) no bisalū will have gone out. (In/for?) 30 days that goes out which has come in.
And this document will take effect [when] (8) Brīyāsa and Budarśaṃʾ place (their) finger(s) [on it].
(9) The following were the witnesses: Puñargaṃ, Khauśpaṃ, Hatkaṃ. — Budarśaṃʾ’s finger, Puñargaṃ’s finger.
(10) Now, whatever may be the *complaints of Brīyāsa, in the future Budarśaṃʾ keeps the account of it for him. (11) Sīḍaka has no dispute there.

comments.comment: 17th year of Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ = 779. Hoernle, 1901, pl. vi, no. 1. Cf. SI M52 (year 20), P103.53.
rū very similar to ū, but rū has right diacritical lower than ū, which has it touching the top of the letter.

translation.line: (1) Year 11, eight days of the month of Cvātaja, in the year of the Tsīṣīs.

(2) This writ is for the reason that Puñārrjāṃ is getting wheat (in the amount of) (3) seven kūsas—it belonged to Puñargaṃ—from the khaysmaṃjā. And in the month of Ttuṃjārā (4) he will deliver cloth: woolen (cloth) 11 chās in length and (5) 30 chās 2 tsunas in width, so that Sīḍaka receives the cloth in the month of Ttuṃjārā. (6) And if he (Sīḍaka) should not receive it, (then) for a five-month period he (Puñārrjāṃ) shall pay one chā interest.
(7) And this writ will take effect when Puñārrjāṃ (8) places (his) finger on it.
(9) Puñārjāṃ’s finger (mark).

comments.comment: 11th year, i.e., of Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ, year of the tsīṣīs (also Hedin 45) = 773. Hoernle, 1901, p. 37. The scribe was forgetful of his subscripts.
. Vowel tops neither quite typical of -ai nor like -ę in pęmīnai.
Like śä, but no space for -au below ki.

Puñārrjāṃ and Puñargaṃ are both mentioned in a list of recipients of large sums of money in SI P 103.36, dated in the year of the ṣṣau Ṣacū (= Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ’s16th or 17th). Puñārrjāṃ is mentioned in D.viii.2 (IOL Khot 3/5) and SI P 98.10. Puñargaṃ is mentioned several times in BL and SI docs. According to SI P 103.6 he comes from Gaysāta.
The meaning of this term, which occurs several times, is not known. In Or.8211/1456 dvī khaysmaje “two khaysmajās” are mentioned.

translation.line: (1) I, Vaśäʾrapuña, and Arrjāṃ embracing the earth (before) the spāta Gaudaka make a report:

(2) I sent (my) son to Ttanvī for 5,000 mūrās. 2,000 mūrās—those I have received in full, (3) and 3,000 thousand—those I have not received in full. When now the spāta Sīḍaka comes to you, those mūrās (4) you collect from him (Ttanvī), (but) don’t give them (yet) to (Sīḍaka). Where the spāta Jī has ... them(?) ... he will take whatever I have(?). (5) Thus Ttanvī is to hand them over,(and then you) give (pay) the mūrās (to Sīḍaka).
Thus (first) you obtain the writ (from him) (6) and do not give (him) the mūrās. Then you shall collect the boy from the spāta.
And it will take effect when (7) he places (his) finger on it. — (8) Arrjāṃ’s finger.

comments.comment: Report from Vaśäʾrapāña and Arrjāṃ to the spāta Gaudaka. The spāta Sīḍaka, Vaśaʾrapuña, and Gaudaka are mentioned together in Or.6396/2 from (Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ’s) 19th year = 781. Hoernle, 1901, p. 37. PLATE 5c.
B. takes this to be a noun meaning “hostage” or “pledge.”

B.: “distribute,” but contexts seem to indicate “hand over, get rid of,” in accordance with the Buddh. terminology, where gvaṣṭ- is “separation”; SI P 103.43 has puṣa gvaścarä pāra-vaysdāṃ, which Emmerick translates as “Hand out (receipts for) the quittance of the debts.”

translation.line: (1) [Of the -th regnal year] of Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ, king of Khotan, of the month of Kaja 22 days, in the year of the ṣṣau Ṣanīra.

This writ (2) (was made) for [this] reason that: Sīḍaka buys ground from Darmapuña in Veṃgulāṃ *from Braṃgāṃ (3) [... owed?] one kūsa 5 khas and one piece of cloth. Darmapuña has delivered. Sīḍaka has received (the land) (4) and two thaṃgas of cotton. Thus Sīḍaka has received this ground.
For a period of 6 autumns, if he has cultivated (only) one plot, (then) (5) whenever Darmapuña has millet and cloth (and?) cotton he shall buy back the earth. Sīḍaka (6) can not *hinder him.
This writ shall then take effect when Darmapuña places his finger on it.
Witness: (7) the parramai *Buttąnaka. Witness: *Japāṇaka. Witness: Surgāṃ from Birgaṃdara.
Darmapuña’s finger.

comments.comment: Regnal year of Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ, year of the ṣṣau Ṣanīra. Buttąnaka is mentioned in docs. from (Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ’s) 20th (Or.6397/1 = Hoernle 7) and 21st (Hedin 4) years = 782-3. Hoernle, 1901, p. 37. PLATE 5b.
B.: “if he makes the one field (?) to be planted” (SD, TV, p. 52, cf. p. 57); cf. Or.6397/1.5 kīra käʾstä īdä.
Cf. LKhot. āhrrī < āhalj- “to control” (SD, TV, p. 57; Studies I, pp. 25-27)?

secondary.siglum: Hoernle 2: KT II, p. 65 (26); SD II/XXVI; SD, TV, p. 52

translation.line: (1) The ṣṣau Phvai-hvuhi orders thus: To the spāta Sīḍaka in Gaysāta and to those men (2) who promised wool cloths and did not deliver the cloths. Now, here for *you the merchant Są̄made and (3) Hattäkaṃ requested 10,300 mūrās. For those mūrās they (= those men?) had handed over 300 pieces of hemp cloth (4) worth 500 [= 15,000?]. I have handed over from them (?) thirty chās of woolen cloth.
When you hear the order, (5) at the expiry of the days, pay the mūrās fully together with interest. If they do not (pay) in full one (or) two it is OK.
(6) The order went out *to you on the 10th day of Ttuṃjārā.

comments.comment: Order from the ṣṣau Phvaiṃ-hvuhi to the spāta Sīḍaka of Gaysāta (also SI P 94.24, 100.9). Hoernle, 1901, pl. vii, 1, no. 5. In KT V, p. 2 (4) and SD, TV, p. 52, this is referred to as “Or.6394.1” and “Or 6394,1 = H2.”
Cf. the situation in SI P 103.35, also about delivery of cloth.

secondary.siglum: Or.6394.2: KT V, p. 2 (5); SD II/XXVI; SD, TV, p. 53

translation.line: (1) The spāta Ṣṣanīraka orders thus: To the haṃdasta Sīḍaka in Gaysāta:

(2) Thus you owe x mūrās per head as well as those for cloth for winter clothes. (3) And those mūrās they requested in the month of Kaja in the Inner Fortress. And I requested them from the *Sogdian (4) with interest. Now, the *Sogdian has come here. When you hear the order bring here those 9,370 mūrās (5) with the interest. The *Sogdian is not going to you. If you do not bring those mūrās here within five days (6) you will have to eat (= suffer) strong penalties.
On the 6th day of Haṃdyaja the order (7) went out to you.

comments.comment: Order from the spāta Ṣṣanīraka to the haṃdasta Sīḍaka in Gaysāta regarding payment. The similar document SI P 103.40 mentions the year of the ṣṣau Ṣacū (= 778-9), and SI P 103.41 mentions a *Sogdian (sūlī). Hoernle, 1901, p. 38.
Cf. SI P 103.42 paṃjvā haḍvā ma thaṃgä ājimyari “bring the tax here within five days!”
Chin. phau, see Intro. Cf. SI P 93.5 [paʾ]jsa phauʾva byehi, SI P 94.4 X[...] ājume phauʾ-v-e parī hauḍä.

translation.line: (1) Year 22, 23 days of the month of Skarihvāra. This writ concerning *tax-payers (is) for the following reason:

line.n: a2 a3 a4 a6 a6 a7

translation.line: (2) Viṃkausa is sending his brother german in lieu of tax (payment of) 5,000 (3) mūrās because Viṃkausa had promised *Sīña of Paʾ x thousand mūrās. (4) And all the villagers of Gaysāta took on this Mūpadatta in lieu of tax (5) 5,000 mūrās (for) ten months. And the villagers took that Mūpadatta in varāysai ... (6) received for tax, which the village haṃdasta, the spāta Sīḍaka ... varāysai (7) ... (But?) this was Mūpadatta’s ... They *received as tax.

(8) If he becomes sick he has seven days’ jurisdiction. And (if) he *remains feverish more (than that) then for him (9) ... work ... and *Mūpadatta himself provides shoes and ... (it). (10) And the spāta provides one garment for him. If that Mūpadatta leaves *still owing work (11) (and) brings a *complaint for (loss of?) day-works and (if) he *disregards the villagers, (then) they shall bring a *complaint for mūrās.
(12) And this writ concerning *tax-payers will take effect when Viṃkausa and Mūpadatta (13) put their fingers on it and the villagers all together put their fingers on it.
(14) These were the witnesses: the spāta Sudaṃ, the spāta Budesa.
(15-22) Brīyāsa’s finger (mark), Viṃkausa, Puñargaṃ, Mūpadatta, Maiyadatta, Japāṇaka, Arrtai, Arsäla, Śalā, Jsajsaka, Pheṃdūka, and Mahvetara’s finger (marks).

comments.comment: Doc. concerning *tax-collectors (thaṃgaurāṃ pīḍaki?). 22nd year (of Väśaʾ Vāhaṃ = 789). The doc. contains provisions for sickness and loss of salary(?), but because of several lacunae and unknown words the sense of many of the provisions escapes us. Hoernle, 1901, p. 39.
Cf. M.T. a.i.0033 (IOL Khot 41/1) paʾ sīña.

B. (SD, TV, p. 4) renders this word as “offer” in the combination kaʾrä varāysai “the offer of the gratuity,” but the expression kaʾrä N.N. in the wood tablets clearly contains the title and name of the scribe; see Studies III, pp. 39-40.
Jsajsaka is a dānapati in Hedin 23.

secondary.siglum: Hoernle 3: KT II, p. 65 (27) = Or.6395.2: KT V, p. 4 (7); SD II/XXVII; SD, TV, p. 54

translation.line: (1) In the 17th regnal year, in the year of the ṣṣau Ṣacū, the 17th day of the month of Rrāhaja. (2) The villagers of Gaysāta have agreed on their tax for the month of Cvātaja.

There were 55 paying men. (3) The tax was 5,500 mūrās, for one man 1,000 mūrās. (4) Only, in this count (were) 8 old men; here *dwelling ... (men) *in full strength (were) (5) 37; ... men of the village (were) 10. All in all there were (6) 55 [= 8 + 37 + 10] men.

comments.comment: Doc. concerning taxes dated in the 17th regnal year (of Väśaʾ Vāhaṃ = 784), year of the ṣau Ṣacū. The ṣau Ṣacū also appears in Or.6400/2.2 (no year) together with Pheṃdūka and Puñargaṃ and in Hedin 4 (21st year) together with Buttąnaka. Hoernle, 1901, pl. vii, 2, no. 8.
Cf. Or.6396/2.2; on samev- samautta-, see KT IV, p. 118.

translation.line: (1) 19th regnal year, on the 29th day of month of Braṃkhaysja.

The spāta Sīḍaka and the villagers all together have assigned the court (2) tax. “Whole” paying men were 41, and “half-work” (men) 12 children and old men. (3) They (were) *Puñaupīkṣa, Jsajsaka, Gaudaka, Cauṣaka, Stavala, {ī x de}, Kāśaka, Svarrnadätta, (4) Vāysaḍa, Upadatta, Valai, Jigeṃḍai, Īrasaṃga, Jsaysayuda, Vaśaʾrapuña.
A “whole” man (5) on state-work accordingly had (the following) *scheduled (work): one man had to deliver 213 mūrās; and a “half” man 106 mūrās.
(6) Mūpadatta: 18 [“whole”?] men and a 7 “half” (men, which amount to) 1,500.
(7) Sābaka; 23 “whole” men and 5 “half-work” men, (which) amounts to 2,000 mūrās
(8) 433 mūrās

comments.comment: Doc. concerning taxes dated in the 19th regnal year (of Väśaʾ Vāhaṃ = 781), agreement between the spāta Sīḍaka and the villagers. Hoernle, 1901, p. 39.
Here vowel marks of lai to the right (not left), but not in line 7.
B.: hvaṃʾḍi, but no trace of second akṣara.
Incomplete akṣara: upper left loop missing.
Faint traces of akṣaras; what B. reads as himārä, looks more like x ñirā.
hālairya is from *hālā-vīria- “half-work’er.” “Whole” men were “workmen”: Or.6401/2.2, M.T. i.17 (IOL Khot 44/5), D. v.4 (IOL Khot W 3), SI P 101.4 hālai hvaṃḍye ... kīrarai hvaṃḍye.
On pravanai, the meaning of which is not clear, see KT IV, p. 70.
Note: The writing and reading of many of the numbers are uncertain and do not add up properly.

secondary.siglum: Hoernle 7: KT II, p. 66 (30); SD II/XXVIII (2); SD, TV, p. 54

translation.line: (1) Year 20, 13 days of the month of Cvātaja, of this king of Khotan, Viśaʾ Vāhaṃ.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6

translation.line: In the third (year) of the ṣṣau (2) Vidyadatta, (this) document of purchase (was) for this reason that Bugura bought three kūśeṃ (?) of earth from Maṃdūsa unmeasured (3) in *Gaṃtsakūḍai for a period of four autumns at the price of 1000 mūrās. The following are *co-terminous of that earth: (4) From the *water (it is) Puñavärṣa’s (land). From the ... (is) Sanekula’s man Kaḍaka’s (land). (5) ... if Bugura has not sown in his plot—if then Maṃdūsa within the four-autumn period (6) buys it back, he shall buy (it) back. Older (then that) it can not be bought back.
And this writ shall take effect (7) when Maṃdūsa puts his mark on it.
These were the witnesses: Witness Arsalaṃ. Witness the parramai (8) Buttąnaka. Witness *Bauḍa. Maṃdūsa’s finger (mark).

comments.comment: Doc. of purchase (gärya-vāḍa) dated in year 20 of Väśaʾ Vāhaṃ (= 782), 3rd year of the ṣṣau Vädyadatta. Hoernle, 1897, pl. v, no. viii. In KT V, p. 5 (10) and SD, TV, p. 54, this doc. is referred to as “Or.6397.1” and “Or 6397,1 = H 7.”
Also dated in a year of the ṣṣau Vidyadatta are SI P 103.26 and perhaps SI P 93.3.

secondary.siglum: Hoernle 4: KT II, p. 65 (28) = Or.6397.2: KT V, p. 5 (11); SD II/XXVIII (1); SD, TV, p. 55

translation.line: (1) In the 20th year, on the tenth day of the month of Kaja. This promissory note (2) (is) for this reason that Hvā Cai Sai had the (following) mūrās *outstanding. These were the ones (3) who requested the mūrās. He had promised Hatkaṃ 125 mūrās. He had promised the spāta (4) Sīḍaka 125. He had promised Pheṃdūka 125 mūrās, Alttāṃ (5) 125, Budarśaṃ 125, Mayadatta 125, Rruhadatta (6) he had promised [...]. (7) [If ...] can not deliver the cloths, then he [shall pay] interest (8) ... 100 mūrās.
Alttāṃ’s finger (mark), Pheṃdūka’s finger (mark), Hatkaṃ’s finger, Budarśaṃ’s finger, Rruhadatta’s finger, Jsajsaka’s finger.

comments.comment: Doc. of debt (*pāra-vastū) dated in year 20 (of Väśaʾ Vāhaṃ = 787). Note the use of separate “double dots” in -ä. Lines 1-2 in Hoernle, 1901, pl. ii, 6.
Cf. Hedin 4.2 KT IV, p. 23 ṣiʾ pāra-vastū pīḍakä ttye pracaina [cu].

translation.line: Thus I have heard, as (=when, how) the Lord Buddha formerly went in (his) career as far as the land of Vaiśālī; he stayed(?) in the Mrakāṭikā grove. 1.

(This) grove was very nice, pleasant, fragrant, very peaceful. There were nice dwellings of various kinds, just as was worthy of the Buddha. Springs, lakes, lotus ponds, pools, fountains, reservoirs (with) fresh water, cool, pure, tasty, quick(?), fragrant, lotuses, utpalas, kumudas, sūmana, caṃbā[ṭala ...].

translation.line: ... those men being ... of themselves ... become. They will fall into that drection, then, ... false roads (kumārga) in the end ... they will become horses (or) camels. (*99) They will carry burdens, they will load [onto them] many ... and they will not take pity on them. They will become very tired, exhausted, and *hurt, ... and distressed. 100

The Lady Dūlakā ordered (this text) to be written together with her son the knower of the Tripiṭaka, the monk Jayabhadra and together with her brothers, the spāta Sīḍaka and the others, and with her sisters.

When they die there they obtain births among men. They become the servants of another and are very ... suffering in inferiority. (*101) When their human life is ended (of) at death they are able to hear the name, vows, puṇyas, and blessings of that buddha ..., (then) they make happiness, in (their) mind bliss [arises, their heart?] *rejoices, all are happy, they ..., they rejoice always. (*102) Then when ... respect great quickly they will obtain [deliverance] from all woes and sufferings, always they will obtain happiness ...

translation.line: (a1) ... *lights, that buddha should be revered by him, (and) he will obtain birth as a man.

line.n: a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

translation.line: Thus ... spoke to him: Whomever it should please in his mind, he will be born in all ten directions, (a4) in Buddha-fields which (are) flawless. Or he whom far away pure, flawless buddha fields (should please), if, however briefly, (a5) he were to reach them, in just that way he must be revered by him. He whom a birth among the *Tuṣita gods pleases, where Maitreya (b1) dwells, in just that way it must be revered by him. He goes straight among the Tuṣita gods. As for those who follow evil false paths, if he has stayed away from [those], (b2) in just that way he must be revered by him, and he (shall) no more walk on false paths. He who has evil dreams at night or who (b3) ... a hundred kinds of confused, unfavorable signs, suddenly falls, or if a (b4) *ghoul [makes him miserable] (or) strength-robbing demons, (then) that Buddha must be revered by him, and they will not be able to harm him. (b5) He who (burns) in fire (or) drowns in water, who ... in ...

translation.line: ... (a1) the stupa ... one should circumambulate it 77 times. And 77 times this (a2) dhāraṇī [and] mantra should be recited, and 77 times this dhāraṇī [and] mantra should be ordered to be written. One should be clean (and) well bathed. It should be written with great homage and while sitting in the middle of a well-cleaned maṇḍala. And the (a4) writer should give (be given?) a donation with seven jewels, and the writer should do homage with outstanding food and drink. And (a5) thus this kalparāja dhāraṇī should be written 77 times and be placed there in the middle of the caitya. Thus one should do homage (b1) to the caitya and clean it. What they do thus in that manner is expounded in this sutra.

The noble son or noble daughter whose life may be even completely destroyed (and) may have left *life, life comes back to him (or her), and he lives (b3) long, and he is delivered from all apāyas. And as for the previous āvaraṇas, on account of which he would have to go to an apāya, (b4) those are [extinguished?] for him. And for 77.000 lord buddhas (b5) [he will have accumulated] roots of goodness. [And] throughout (re)births he will be rid of all sins. And in all (re)births he *will be born remembering previous births.

translation.line: Welfare! Thus I had heard that the hail!
daśabala cakravartin Śākyamuni, the Lord Buddha,
had finished his buddha deeds. Staying there
a child servant ...
he deigned to go all the way to the Nairañjana river.
Hail to the lord buddhas standing in the ten directions,
standing in the world spheres.
In the Year of the Horse, of the month of Haṃdyaja 16th day. ...
Equipped with exalted, heavy, extended merits and roots of goodness. ...

comments.comment: Drafts of letter. Lines 1 and 21 begin at opposite ends of the scroll. At end of scroll next to the Chinese name of the sutra (2 lines not mentioned by Enoki) several Khotanese akṣaras (repeated: tcī ḍainä) and before line 21 two lines not read by Bailey but like line 35. Lines 1-20 written with thick pen. On the back of Chinese Saddharma¬puṇḍarīka. Lines 1-20 in Hoernle, 1911, pl. III facing p. 456 (Hoernle has 19 lines, but he omitted line 4 in his count).

translation.line: I make a report to the court thus: The humble servant, as for him before now to you ...
the parents ... thus there was water and earth. On account of the royal words (when?) you learn(?) the order ...
the august one (U ū huangzhu) bought the servant (girl?) Masarīka from Ysagāña. And now
he does not at all carry that word in his ears(?). Now (my) refuge is to the court. If the word
*is not in your ears(?), he carries (off) Masarīka, who(?) does the work on the water and land for him.
But if he does not *perform our ..., ...
As for him before now to you, if ... the word of the huangzhu is not in your ears(?), ... he
carries off the ... Masarīka, who(?) does the work on the water and land for him, which (is) the ...
of the great huangzhu. Thus I make report.
To the one equipped with great merits and roots of goodness. From(?) the keepers of the land (to) the humble servant Yū *Saṃgalaka.
(On me) the humble servant here in Ganzhou the order *descended (lit.: sat down?) that: There was a deed of purchase,
and it stood at sixty jin. The humble servant ... On the road the camels died
and ... accordingly were the horses. To the great Lady of China and the great huangzhu thus
honey, *soft molasses, sugar, sweetmeats, ..., pearls, ..., conches. Very much
the consort’s (furen ˚ w) life declined(?). Seven times daily she ...
If it helps her in this life ... led her to kṣānti(?). ...
Then she is there delighted, ... In every hand(?), accept(?) the child called Īniysikhyaṣe(?), a great ... has come to him. There is an orphan(?) here ...
... called Mayamūva. Subsequently one came. Very much his groins were ... and
... splits ... The same for us(?)
happiness which there is here in the heart. With pleasure in the heart
I have come to the same ... A separate(?) lotus appeared: White and red, soft. ...
... appeared. They look(?). ...
... when there ... remains in the (various) directions(?). Always I say(?)
(TRIALS?)
... it was encumbent upon him.
I make a report to the court, the humble servant Sanaka. Upon the humble servant here an order descended:
Make them look (You must go?) to Shazhou. ... hither the order was: Horses, clothes
they must collect well. Now Tsvaḍa Pada has things (= to pay with?), but he has not promised anything(?).
) ... now (my) refuge is to the court. If the Tibetans here in Akuśī(?) gather orders ... the court
if I can undertake the royal order ...
I make a report asking about the health in reverence of the Yauvarāja, of the lineage of the Vyāśas, equipped with merits and roots of goodness like great suns, the humble servant

Yu Dāhaʾ Paḍi, if thus now at this time and season of the year he may be well, healthy, and at peace. Therefore am I (his) humble servant(?). I shall not die as long as long as I have delight in you(?). And ... sufferings *are ... Fears,
sorrows, which are obtained because of immortality(?), when there will be places for me, when
they become ... black ... calves ... only from joy
dwells in the palace ... I lie down at night the cocks call the law to us(?).
) ... From that man(?) called Tcyā Kvä Khīmu Cu, ...
Thus I make report to the court, the humble servant Kharasanaña, to the great ... Masters *I make report, the humble servant Pacaka from Baramai, the humble servant....

comments.comment: On the back of Chinese Buddhabhāṣita-buddhanāma-sūtra. Bailey, SD, TV, p. 118: “This manuscript is in an unskilled hand with many misunderstood words; it may be a school exercise.” Lines 1-37 on Ser., pl. CXLVII.

translation.line: In the Year of the Sheep, ninth day of the month of Cvātaja. This memo (is) for the reason that Panakā of Baramya *Ttūnakāṃ, when he went as envoy and took one Chinese (woman) here. And he submitted the following case concerning it(?): Take heed of the people of the land(?)!
And I make (her) my wife. The wife belonging to the house (her) I expel. That was the case he submitted. When that
... did not take the Chinese (woman as a) lawful (one). ... Authoritative when with him(?) this Panakā places her akṣara.
This much work is to be done in Shazhou by young Cīnä, together with ... Together with the envoys: Saṃgalaka and the others who are going to Ganzhou, and
*Sudatta and the others who are going to Shuofang, the work must be done. When they set out here in the (Golden) Land (to go) to you
, there were three kinds of envoys. In the hand of each and every one (were) yellow orders. Under each and every
red coat the envoys wear a ... on the shoulder. Wherever they dismount, if there is no tree there, there he must tie on a ...
and place the orders on top of it. And they rise very early. All must be ... and their orders must be ...
The first horse must be *employed for the orders. They must watch until the order-bearer mounts. And first of all
you must come pronto(?) and *deliver the order as soon as possible. I make a report to the court: For (each) one so much is to be prepared: wine (and) food for the small princes(?).
Then we remembered you. Suddenly I got a headache. ...
there where you understand the speech.

comments.comment: Lines 1-17 in SD IV, pl. XC; SD, TV, pp. 115-17.

translation.line: ... deign to ... good (and) pure mind:
“I go to the refuge of the Lord Buddha, I go to the refuge of the Law, I go to the refuge of the bhikṣusaṅgha,
I go to the refuge of the bhikṣusaṅgha assembly, a second time, a third
time. The great prince deigns to accept the refuge of the Lord Buddha, the Law, and the bhikṣusaṅgha jewel. May he not
deign to take birth in those three great apāyas without vows.
Deign utter: As I am now bowing with good
faith and with the three saṃskāras
with the priority of the Lord Buddha, the bhikṣusaṅgha assembly ...
with a view (to all those), may he deign to give this beggar food and drink.
May he deign to restrain himself from the all those ten great sins,
and may he deign to fare in the *performance of the ten great goodnesses,
namely, the three kinds with the body,
the four kinds with the tongue, (and) the three kinds with the mind. Just as
they deigned utter firstly, thus secondly, thus thirdly.
... Deign utter: This food and drink ... former(?)
trivarga ... Deign give the *ransom of the production of continuation of his life.
{(18) Welfare! I go in reverence with my forehead to the exalted buddha (18) body of the Law, pure may he deign to (place?) the body in the ten bhūmis(?).}
May they succeed by these merits (and) roots of goodness. When he writes to you,
, for him are fulfilled the six pāramitās, the ten bhūmis, the ten powers,
(his) wishes are fulfilled, all living beings (
will become buddhas in the world. O great prince,
deign thereafter to realize the all-supreme bodhi of the buddhas!

comments.comment: On the back of Chinese “śāstra explaining the anitya or uncertainty of all things” (Enoki).

recto.line: /// a haʾ na ā rrdä māṃ gä
pa he rą̄ ñä • heṃ je ha śä tca beʾ ją̄ kä pę ṇḍai : : ī raṃ de kuṃ jsa ha maṃ gä vī śtā ñä
• nau ka ā rą̄ ñä • u lį̄ ñe tcā ra jsä pę ṇdai pa dį̄ mą̄ ñä • pa skyā ṣṭä
hvą̄ʾ ñą̄ ñä • gu rgu la bų̄ʾ u ha lī rai tti hā ha maṃ gä vī śtą̄ ñä • ā rą̄ ñä •
hā haṃ brrī hą̄ ñä • gvīʾ hye bī ysma jsä pa he rą̄ ñä • ṣiʾ pę ṇḍai ā yvą̄ ñä • u
di rye u rä biṃ dä nī śą̄ ñä • dū va rä jiṃ dä u ha śä : : ba hauʾ yä • bau ṇva ṣa va rä
hą maṃ gä vi śtą̄ ñä • haṃ tsä kū ṭą̄ ñä • ha śä biṃ dä ba ñą̄ ñä • he ji ha śä
jiṃ dä : : vą̄ mī rāṃ • a ysāʾ yä • pu ṣṭa rą̄ na • hu ṣkyä ttra he • ā ḍä • hą̄ mai
• bi śä hą maṃ gä vī śtą ñä • nau ka ā rą̄ ñä • mau na pā chai • ya mai rū nä
gū ma lyą̄ ñä • biṃ dai sa da lūṃ pa rkū ną̄ ñä • khā ysą̄ ña ba ñą̄ ñä hai jä ha śä
jiṃ dä • u pa ṣkā sā : : śvą̄ ña gū ra • hu ṣkyi ttra he • ha maṃ gä vi śtą̄ ñä •
kū ṭą̄ ñä • hą̄ mai hā haṃ brrī hą̄ ñä • mau na pā chai khā ysą̄ ña ba ñą̄ ñä ha śä
pę ṇḍai : : pu ṣṭi rą̄ na • hu ṣkyä ttra he • haṃ ga • mi jsā ka • ā ḍä • hą̄ mai • bau ṇva
ṣa va rä • rā jā na mva • dā jsaṃ dai • a ṣṇų̄ ha • kāṃ jsą • kāṃ bā • tta bi śä hą ma gä
vī śtą̄ ñä nau kä ā rą̄ ñä mau na pā chai gų̄ mi lyą̄ ñä • beṃ dai ā rä • hū ra ṣṭi pa rkū ną̄ ñä
ṣiʾ da śāṃ gä ną̄ ma pi ṇḍai khā ysą̄ ña ba ñą̄ ñä ha śä jiṃ dä : : hu ṣkyi ttra he
į̄ raṃ de • mu jsā ka • mau hī ya pu rga • hą ma gä vi śtą̄ ñä ā rą̄ ñä • mau na pā chai •
maṃ gā rä gvīʾ haʾ rūṃ na gų̄ ma lyą̄ ñä • bi dai ku ṣṭi pa rkū ną̄ ñä • khā ysā ña ba ñą̄ ñä
ha śä jiṃ dä u jsa he ra vį̄ ne : : cu pā ha svīṃ dä ṣiʾ va pį ṇḍai • ga nį̄ ma bī sai
kuṃ bā pa tte vą̄ ña • u ā rą̄ ñä • pa ysā ya bi sā nāṃ ji tce rā • u maṃ gā ra
mau hī ye pu rgyä na ṣiʾ pį ṇḍai pā chai • maṃ gā rä gvīʾ haʾ rūṃ na gų̄ ma lyą̄ ñä • pāṃ biṃ dä ba ñą̄ ñä
• ha svai jiṃ dä : : ī raṃ dāṃ hī ye pi rä grą̄ mū cä bį̄ nā ją̄ ñä • ku jsa vī nai
rūṃ na gū ma lyą̄ ñä • biṃ dai sa dä lūṃ pa rku ną̄ ñä • pāṃ biṃ dä ba ñą̄ ñä ha svai ji dä
: : kuṃ jsa • ysā lva • ma hā bau jä • ysī ḍā spye • ha maṃ gā vī śtą̄ ñä nau kä ā rą̄ ñä • ba hau ya
jsä pa he rā ñä • tti ñye ha śi ji nā kä pę ṇḍai : : śī pau • śī bų̄ʾ • ha maṃ gä vī śtą̄ ñä
• haṃ tsä kū ṭą̄ ñä • gvīʾ haʾ rūṃ nä mū rą̄ ñä • heṃ je ttau dye ha śa biṃ dā ṣṭi pį ṃḍai : :
hu ṣkyä ttra he • mau hī ya pu rga • ī raṃ de • ha maṃ gä vī śtą̄ ñä • kū ṭą̄ ñä maṃ gā rä rrū
mau nä ṣiʾ pę ṇḍai pā chai • maṃ gā rä gvīʾ häʾ rų̄ na gų̄ ma lyą̄ ñä bi dai hā ku ṣṭä pa rkū ną̄ ñä •
ha śä jiṃ dä hų ma bā va pa śtä : : svaṃ na gī rai • hau ṣkä gū ra • gvīʾ haʾ : rūṃ na hą maṃ gä śtā kä
• ku ṭą̄ ñä • gvīʾ hye bī ysmä jsa pa he rą̄ ñä ṣiʾ pe ḍai hī ya ttą ñä ha śä jeṃ dä styū da : :
a rū va • rau sta rä • kuṃ jsa • hau ṣka gū ra • pī ha maṃ gä vī śtā ñä • nau kä kū ṭą̄ ñä gvīʾ haʾ
rūṃ na mū rą̄ ñä ṣiʾ ysų̄ rgä vi ra nāṃ ha śä ji nā kä peṃ ḍai : : tti vā ja rä bi dā ṣṭä
pį ṇḍaṃ • bū ysį̄ ña mā stai • nī ya kä • haṃ tsä mū rą̄ ñä biṃ dä hā śa ka rä pa rkų̄ ną̄ ñä
u hī śaʾ ā ṣkä • ja rä biṃ dä ba ñą̄ ñä ja tte : : bū ysį̄ ña mā stai • u śī lā ja ttä
haṃ tsä haṃ brrī hą̄ ñä kaṃ gyä biṃ dä ñų̄ ṣṭyą̄ ñä ja ra biṃ dā ṣṭä peṃ dai : : kuṃ jsa • kuṃ bā
• ysa rūṃ mau gä • rī ysū • hą maṃ gä vī śtą̄ ñä • kū ṭą̄ ñä • ṣvī da na ṣiʾ peṃ ḍai pā chai
• bi dai śa ka rä pa rkū ną̄ ñä ha śä jiṃ dä ū ū ysą na ā phā rä : : ī raṃ de • tha rka
mi jsā • dų̄ ma hau ṣṭä gū ra • kūṃ jsa • drrą̄ ma ttį̄ ma • ū lį̄ ña tcā ra • rau sta rä • bū ysį̄ ña
pį̄ • ha maṃ gä vī śtą̄ ñä nau ka kū ṭą̄ ñä ṣiʾ piṃ ḍai haṃ brrī hą̄ ñä ja rä biṃ dä ba ñą̄ ñä
• hiṃ ja ha śä ji dä u phā häʾ : : : gū ra • kuṃ jsa • hai nai caṃ da • rrī ysų̄ • ha maṃ gä
vī śtą̄ ñä nau ka ku ṭą̄ ña • ṣvī da na pā chai • ja rrä biṃ dä khai ya ji nā kä piṃ ḍai :
: : hau ṣka gū ra • rų̄ nai • ma hā bau jä • haṃ ga • hą ma gä vī śtą̄ ñä

transcription.prose:
/// ahaʾna ārrdä māṃgä
paherą̄ñä • heṃje haśä tcabeʾją̄kä pęṇḍai : : īraṃde kuṃjsa hamaṃgä vīśtāñä
• nauka ārą̄ñä • ulį̄ñe tcāra jsä pęṇdai padį̄mą̄ñä • paskyāṣṭä
hvą̄ʾñą̄ñä • gurgula bų̄ʾ u halīrai tti hā hamaṃgä vīśtą̄ñä • ārą̄ñä •
hā haṃbrrīhą̄ñä • gvīʾhye bīysma jsä paherą̄ñä • ṣiʾ pęṇḍai āyvą̄ñä • u
dirye urä biṃdä nīśą̄ñä • dūvarä jiṃdä u haśä : : bahauʾyä • bauṇva ṣavarä
hąmaṃgä viśtą̄ñä • haṃtsä kūṭą̄ñä • haśä biṃdä bañą̄ñä • heji haśä
jiṃdä : : vą̄mīrāṃ • aysāʾyä • puṣṭarą̄na • huṣkyä ttrahe • āḍä • hą̄mai
• biśä hąmaṃgä vīśtąñä • nauka ārą̄ñä • mauna pāchai • yamai rūnä
gūmalyą̄ñä • biṃdai sadalūṃ parkūną̄ñä • khāysą̄ña bañą̄ñä haijä haśä
jiṃdä • u paṣkāsā : : śvą̄ña gūra • huṣkyi ttrahe • hamaṃgä viśtą̄ñä •
kūṭą̄ñä • hą̄mai hā haṃbrrīhą̄ñä • mauna pāchai khāysą̄ña bañą̄ñä haśä
pęṇḍai : : puṣṭirą̄na • huṣkyä ttrahe • haṃga • mijsāka • āḍä • hą̄mai • bauṇva
ṣavarä • rājānamva • dājsaṃdai • aṣṇų̄ha • kāṃjsą • kāṃbā • tta biśä hąmagä
vīśtą̄ñä naukä ārą̄ñä mauna pāchai gų̄milyą̄ñä • beṃdai ārä • hūraṣṭi parkūną̄ñä
ṣiʾ daśāṃgä ną̄ma piṇḍai khāysą̄ña bañą̄ñä haśä jiṃdä : : huṣkyi ttrahe
į̄raṃde • mujsāka • mau hīya purga • hąmagä viśtą̄ñä ārą̄ñä • mauna pāchai •
maṃgārä gvīʾhaʾ rūṃna gų̄malyą̄ñä • bidai kuṣṭi parkūną̄ñä • khāysāña bañą̄ñä
haśä jiṃdä u jsahera vį̄ne : : cu pā hasvīṃdä ṣiʾ va pįṇḍai • ganį̄ma bīsai
kuṃbā pattevą̄ña • u ārą̄ñä • paysāya bisā nāṃji tcerā • u maṃgāra
mau hīye purgyäna ṣiʾ pįṇḍai pāchai • maṃgārä gvīʾhaʾ rūṃna gų̄malyą̄ñä • pāṃ biṃdä bañą̄ñä
• hasvai jiṃdä : : īraṃdāṃ hīye pirä grą̄mūcä bį̄nāją̄ñä • kujsavīnai
rūṃna gūmalyą̄ñä • biṃdai sadälūṃ parkuną̄ñä • pāṃ biṃdä bañą̄ñä hasvai jidä
: : kuṃjsa • ysālva • mahābaujä • ysīḍā spye • hamaṃgā vīśtą̄ñä naukä ārą̄ñä • bahauya
jsä paherāñä • ttiñye haśi jinākä pęṇḍai : : śī pau • śī bų̄ʾ • hamaṃgä vīśtą̄ñä
• haṃtsä kūṭą̄ñä • gvīʾhaʾ rūṃnä mūrą̄ñä • heṃje ttaudye haśa biṃdāṣṭi pįṃḍai : :
huṣkyä ttrahe • mau hīya purga • īraṃde • hamaṃgä vīśtą̄ñä • kūṭą̄ñä maṃgārä rrū
maunä ṣiʾ pęṇḍai pāchai • maṃgārä gvīʾhäʾ rų̄na gų̄malyą̄ñä bidai hā kuṣṭä parkūną̄ñä •
haśä jiṃdä hųma bāva paśtä : : svaṃnagīrai • hauṣkä gūra • gvīʾhaʾ : rūṃna hąmaṃgä śtākä
• kuṭą̄ñä • gvīʾhye bīysmä jsa paherą̄ñä ṣiʾ peḍai hīya ttąñä haśä jeṃdä styūda : :
arūva • raustarä • kuṃjsa • hauṣka gūra • pī hamaṃgä vīśtāñä • naukä kūṭą̄ñä gvīʾhaʾ
rūṃna mūrą̄ñä ṣiʾ ysų̄rgä viranāṃ haśä jinākä peṃḍai : : tti vā jarä bidāṣṭä

translation.line: ... with ... a ground bean should be soaked. (Such) a pill destroys red swelling. Castoroil and sesame should be placed in equal quantities
and finely ground. It should be made into a pill with camel’s fat. Afterward
it should be dried. Perfume of bdellium and myrobalan should be placed in equal quantities and ground
and blended into it. It should be soaked with cow’s urine. The pill should be heated and
placed on the lower abdomen. It removes enlargement of the abdomen and swelling. bahauʾya, bauṇva, ṣavara
should be placed in equal quantities and pounded together. It should be bound on the swelling. It removes red swelling. vmīrāṃ, aysāʾya, bird cherry(?), dry radishes, and ground flour
should all be placed in equal quantities and finely ground. It should be cooked with *wine. yamaka oil
should be mixed in. Rock salt should be sprinkled on it. It should be bound on the gut. It removes red swelling
and constipation of urine. ... grapes and dry radishes should be placed in equal quantities
and pounded. Flour should be mixed into it. It should be cooked with *wine and bound on the gut. (It makes)
a pill against swelling. Bird cherry(?), dry radishes, bladder sorrel marrow, ground flour, bauṇva,
ṣavara, rājānamva to be burnt(?), pigeon dung, sesame, and linseed
should all be placed in equal quantities finely ground. It should be cooked with *wine and mixed. Sweet flag and orrisroot should be sprinkled on it.
This pill, which is called daśāṃga, should be bound on the gut. It removes red swelling. Dry radishes,
castor oil plant, mujsāka, and the dregs of *wine should be placed in equal quantities and ground. It should be cooked with *wine
and mixed with old ghee. Costus should be sprinkled on it. It should be bound on the gut.
It removes red swelling stomach pains. When the feet are swollen, this is the pill:
the linseed in wheat(?) should be heated and ground. ... should be made, and a pill should be made
with the dregs of *wine. It should be mixed with old cow’s urine. It should be bound on the feet.
It removes the swelling. Leaves of castor oil plant should be soaked
and mixed with sesame oil. Rock salt should be sprinkled on it. It should be bound on the feet. It removes the swelling.
Sesame, turneric, liquorice plant, and yellow flowers should be placed in equal quantities and finely ground.
It should be soaked with bahauya. (Such) a pill destroys swelling of the skin. White onion(?) and white perfume should be placed in equal quantities

and pounded together. It should be kneeded with ghee. (Such) a pill is applied against red, warm swelling. Dry radishes, the dregs of *wine, and castor oil plant should be placed in equal quantities and pounded.
The pill should be cooked in old oil and *wine. It should be mixed with old ghee and costus should be sprinkled on it.
It removes the swelling. ... root, ..., red ochre, should be *placed in equal quantities with dried grapes, cow’s oil
and pounded. It should be soaked in cow’s urine. This pill removes hard swelling of the skin.

..., mudar, sesame, dry grapes, and fat should be placed in equal quantities and finely pounded. It should be kneeded with cow’s oil. This pill is a remover of swelling of wounds. These are the pills applied against liver (swelling). Goat’s brains should be kneeded together, sugar should be sprinkled on it,
and hīśaʾ. It should be bound on the liver (and the ailment) is removed. Goat’s brains
should be mixed together, and wrapped on to the skin. (Such) a pill is applied against liver (swelling). Sesame, linseed,
green beans, and rice should be placed in equal quantities and pounded. This pill should be cooked with milk.
Sugar should be sprinkled on it. It removes the swelling and disturbance of the breath. Castor oil plant, tharka,
marrow, ... grapes, sesame, pomegranate seed, camel’s fat, mudar, goat’s
fat should be placed in equal quantities and finely pounded. The pill should be mixed and bound on the liver. It removes red swelling and cough. Grapes, sesame, red sandal, and rice
should be placed in equal quantities and finely pounded. It should be cooked with milk. (Bound) on the liver (such) a pill is the remover of aches.
Dry grapes, oil, costus, and bladder sorrel should be placed in equal quantities ...

comments.comment: On the back of Chinese “Sūtra of the great good means” and “part of a story of Kalyānakarī and Pāpakarī” (Enoki). Very regular cursive ductus. Follows P 2893 (Maggi).
On the back of Chinese Saddharmapuṇḍarīka. Lines 01-42 love poem, lines 44-223 the Sudhanāvadāna, lines 224-386 the “Book of Vimalakīrti.”
Synoptic edition of the various manuscripts (also P 2896, 2956, 2895, 2022, and 2025) in Dresden, 1977b. See also Kumamoto, 2000. Guide2 [19.1].

translation.line: ... from ... rays come out. Ācausta the fourth: until it burns the kleśas without remainder. Sudurjayā (is)
the *fifth bhūmi, the one *difficult to conquer: it conquers all kleśas. The sixth bhūmi is called Abhimukhā; there all buddhas are in full view.

Durāgamā is the seventh bhūmi; by it saṃsāra becomes distant. Acalā is to be known as the eighth; there the dharma-kāya is unshaken, anābhoga; at that time in the eighth bhūmi pure rays come out of themselves
by which there shines forth ... A great jeweled lotus full of rays sits on it. Much at that time appeared on it.
They study. He takes a consecration of bodhi. The beings in the five stages at that time receive refuge
by (his) ... of rays. Then he delivers many billions of beings. Sādhamā, that is the ninth bhūmi. There there is great success.
However many buddha mysteries there are he realizes and recognizes them all. As for the tenth, that is the Dharmameghā,
the pure cloud of the Law. There he obtains the omni¬science of the buddhas, the ten powers. He conducts the vimāna of the sun.
Not even one is to be known separately of the three bodies of the buddhas, their svabhāva(?). In that manner by the power of the one dharma-kāya(?).
Before them a pure sāmbhogika(?) buddha. From the sāmbhoga-kāya come forth many transformed buddhas.
As many as there are in all the hair pores of the sāmbhogika(?) buddha, so many thousands of billions of rays. From the rays
transformed buddhas next (emerge). On account of the anuloma of (their) compassion all the world spheres appear. Even the one born from the side
or who realizes bodhi or who smashes Māra, performs the teaching until
the one who reaches nirvana appears: all the nirmāṇika buddhas.
Thus (I have) heard: In a purified field
the viewing of the Buddha is (possible), and similarly in a disturbed field. Then, which is the field that is pure (or) disturbed?

How is that to be known? And how is the viewing of the Buddha there? Teach us that matter! It is said: Then he is to be known in a purified field, he in whose mind nature (prakṛti) is pure, where views (dṛṣṭi) and notions (saṃjñā) have ceased. There the Buddha
dwells undisturbed. That mind which is not yet becoming pure, yoked and bound to views, that is to be known as a disturbed field,
based on nature (prakṛti). ... How is one then to see in the ten directions the buddhas arisen before one’s eyes?
Convey to us now that matter on account of the anuloma of your compassion! It is said: Thus all the buddhas are equal to just one buddha.
All the natures are of the (same) own being (svabhāva) as the dharma-kāya, without marks and characteristics (nimitta, lakṣaṇa). When one recognizes (that) the dharma-kāya
of all the buddhas (is) one, then in one and the same instant at that time all the buddhas appear before one’s eyes.
In the sutra, in the Candrapradīpa, in the mystery of the Buddha as many buddhas appear vālamātra on the tip of one hair.
Thus (I have) heard: Just like the grits and sands in the Ganges, together with all the buddha fields he ...
Then how is the matter to be known that they are accomodated on the tip of one hair? It is said: Then how is the samādhi undisturbed? How are they accomodated
on the tip of a hair? So many are the buddhas in the place of the tip of one hair during the samādhi as
the grits and sands of the Ganges together with all the buddha fields. The dharma-kāya is by nature altogether without marks and characteristics.
*Consequently, therefore, the sphere of the Law borderless (and) filled with buddhas altogether is not (even) the size of a hair.
That place where the lord buddhas do not dwell, by the pure eye of the Law, by which all the buddhas appear,
together with all the buddha fileds, by the power of the samādhi it is obtained. Great ṛddhi-pādas, secondary (and)
primary marks it brings(?), the great knowledge of the buddhas, all in the samādhi. And (I have) also heard:
A drop of water, that much it is not extinguished(?) in the hand of Vijayaśākhī(?). On him illness settled. He then on the shoulder
pulled out (?) filled with herbs. He threw that herb on the ... However, it did not
... nor did it cleanse the illness. Without kriyā he went to ... This is similar to the bodhisattva who only
with words seeks bodhi. He is not intent on the samādhi, bodhi (remains) distant from him. He who concentrates on the anābhoga
career (and) does not worry(?), his samādhi is to be known as very close to right bodhi.
And as he said in the omniscient sutra, in the Mañjuśrī-parivarta in the Tathāgatajñānasamudra-sūtra: And an elephant ... When they know all things to be unoriginated, (then) their
knowledge (kauśalya?) is very great at the time of samādhi those buddhas are not(?) to be known as undisturbed at that time.
Then in the Vajramaṇḍala-sūtra, in the great buddha mystery, it is said: Desire, anger,
folly (are) all to be known as bodhi(?). And in the Karmāvaraṇaviśuddhi-sūtra, there it is
said: The obstructions of desire, anger, folly (are) the obstructions of the Buddha, the Law, and the bhikṣusaṅgha. How does that ...
agree mutually? But that which he calls a mystery (is it?) out of compassion, and also
on account of profit for beings?
It is said: Then bodhi is such with respect to nature like the cloudless
sky—nevertheless there come upon it lightening or ... clouds. Thus folly, desire,
anger, the kleśas, (upon) the ... sky(?), all from outside to
inside never in the three times are they found. In that manner all the dharmas
are empty of non-grasping(?), where there is no dharma even the size of an instant. And that is bodhi. Now it is said precisely: obstruction. How much do great bodhisattvas have?
He is not to be called a bodhisattva who has notions (saṃjñā) of anger, desire, folly.

He who has any, for him that is an obstruction caused by acts (karmāvaraṇa). He is not to be called a bodhisattva who has a notion of the Buddha, the Law, and the bhikṣusaṅgha. That is a great obstruction for him to bodhi.
He is not to be called a bodhisattva. And whichever bodhisattva sees the *element of anger
in the *element of nirvana, for him the obstruction caused by acts is purified. And whichever bodhisattva
sees the *element of folly in the *element of nirvana, for him the obstruction caused by acts is purified.
And whichever bodhisattva sees the *element of desire
in the *element of nirvana, for him the obstruction caused by acts is purified. And whichever bodhisattva sees a pupil
as a non-pupil, for him the obstruction caused by acts is purified.
And whichever bodhisattva sees the Buddha, the Law, and, finally, the bhikṣusaṅgha, of the nature of equality,
that bodhisattva is ... And whichever bodhisattva recognizes all things as empty,
unoriginated, undestroyed, extinguished, that bodhisattva is ... And whichever
bodhisattva wishes to serve pleasantly(?) all the buddhas of the three times with divine worship,
in his exalted(?) samādhi he needs a mind undisturbed, unsupported. Thus they will be worship-worthy for him (worshiped by him),
all the buddhas of the three times. And whichever bodhisattva seeks knowledge,
however many, without exception, sutras he wishes to learn, ... he must produce (bhāvaya) a samādhi without vikalpa, undisturbed. As soon as(?) he has explained (it), he understands (adhimuc-)
the meanings all sutras. Whoever may hear(?) this right pure Law of the buddhas obtain
great knowledge. They become free from obstructions, like the sky, undisturbed in mind. They go to the other world, they explain with the help of the bhāvanā the release of pure nirvana.

The Anantamukhanirhāra-sūtra, in which the eight akṣaras are expounded, how are the meanings of the akṣaras of the name of that sutra to be known? It is said: In that sutra bodhi is expounded by many entrances into the Law (dharma-mukha). Whoever makes a bhāvanā there, he explains in this life beginning with deliverance(?). By the
akṣara pa the paramārtha-dharma as unobstructed, selfless, empty, extinguished. The completion for him is
deliverance(?). The akṣara la is to be known as the lakṣaṇas.
Not with those is the Buddha to be appropriated. There the dharma-kāya is without marks and characteristics.
Next, about the akṣara ba, (its) meaning is the viewing of pure equality. For whom his
dharmas are appropriated through folly, there for the knowledgeable ones they are all one and the same. About the akṣara ka, the meaning is he recognizes
the fruition of acts, when he neither obtains acts nor fruition, that is to be known as the confession of acts.
The akṣara called ja, its meaning is birth, aging, and death. They are all unoriginated, undestroyed,
unobtained, that is to be known as the understanding of the Law. About the akṣara dha, the meaning is dhāraṇīs and

displays, markless, empty, without desires, it is nirvāṇa-dharmathā(?). The akṣara śa is śamatha, extinction, the viewing of ..., the Law, empty (are) all the dharmas, exting-uished, there the samādhi is undisturbed. The akṣara kṣa is first extinguished, empty are all the dharmas, without essence, in which there is not a dharma the size of an instant. That is just pure nirvana. If nirvana was really uniform and possessed of guṇas, the Buddha
with all his hearers would enter into it with the assembly (of monks). Where the views have ceased altogether, notions, attachments,
and saṃskāras, there, there is no disturbance, (but) really nirvana. As for the restraint (śīla) (and)
saṃvara of the bodhisattvas, how is that to be known? How is one to stand in the command of the right *assembly of the buddhas of the three times?
It is said to you: How does he seem to you (who says): “Only I practice restrain; those are not practicing restraint”? He possesses bad śīla
... he who does not stand in the non-dual, pure, practice of restraint. He who perceives the dharmas as being without marks (nimitta?)
extended thus in the first khara(?), he is the upholder of the buddhas’ command. Like birds in the sky do not (...)
and do not ... the senses, for him monkhood is pure, faultless. He who does not obtain ... dharmas, for him (his) mind
will go right into (his) jurisdiction. He who does not think mind nor dharmas is to be known as close to bodhi. Then Vimalakīrti,
the exalted great bodhi-seeker, said: “Now I shall introduce Mount Sumeru all the way
into a mustard (seed), (and) neither will Mount Sumeru decrease, nor the mustard seed increase more than *before. Explain the meaning
to us now so far.” It is said to you: The mustard seed, that is to be known as views. Mount Sumeru (is) the Law
(and) stands undisturbed. By the Law that view ceases, and there is no decrease nor increase there. When, with knowledge,
one views it thus, then there is no dharma even the size of an instant. When the view is ... then ... in one and the same instant the Law
will stand. The flames of a lit fire will not be not supported on it ...
That is precisely the nature of the fire. When the samādhi stands undisturbed, (it is) just like the sky without clouds.

All the supports are lost, the notions, the attachments, the saṃskāras. Just like the Agniśauca garment, when they throw it into the fire, all its impurity is burnt (away), (and) the garment remains there clean.a Just so in that manner all the obstructions are burnt (away) by the fire of absence of vikalpas, (and) the bodhi-citta remains there pure. When the bodhisattva sees that unthinkable escape (and) extinction, it is just saṃsāra and saṃskāra, (then) (328) nirvana stands (there) pure.
Next the Licchavi king said to Vimalakīrti, the bodhisattva: He seizes all the roads(?) in the triple-thousand (world)
in (his) mouth. The four great oceans, which
are filled with water, all those he introduces into (his) stomach, he accomodated them without remainder.
All that such great power belongs to the bodhisattva so exalted.
Now convey to us the meaning (of that)! It is said to you: The ... are to be known as just mind,
..., flighty, *empty. All the ... in the triple-thousand (world), in the 500 ..., when
one looks at them, knowledge having arisen(?), all its career is destroyed, it becomes just mind (and) the samādhi stands
undisturbed. Those four great oceans are to be known in the knowledge of the buddha(s). All that knowledge, without remainder,
the bodhisattva introduces into (his) mind. There will be no ... there, not even the size of a hair, no disturbance (or) destruction.
They will career in the land of the buddhas just by the anābhoga career.
Then the good man Vimalakīrti at that time (said?): When not (even) one ... from the ten directions, (then) the bodhi-seekers
went thither. All ... thither in space great seats in count
8000. They all, without remainder, were accomodated on it. They sat down upon the seats in the ten
bhūmis, those bodhisattvas. And that house did not increase at all! How was that assembly accomodated on it?
It is said *to you: Vimalakīrti, for them this house(?) is of the sphere of the Law(?), pure. As for the seats and
the bodhisattvas, they are the dharma-kāya and (its) svabhāva, (and so) they are accomodated on the tip of one hair, (
all the buddhas of the three times together with all (their) buddha fields. The nature of the dharma-kāya is that very one. If, Vimalakīrti,
one oneself realized the release (vimokṣa) of the buddhas for the sake of compassion, a being would just appear
in the form of a layman. Then how would eons be introduced into instants or how fields into atoms? Please

listen to the meaning (of this), the great buddha mystery! It is said to you: Eons are to be known as just views. Views are introduced into an instant. Into whatever instant a view reaches, in the very same instant the Law (also) stands. ... in each instant all the buddhas of the three times together with (their) buddha fields
appear in an atom. Where there is no dharma not even the size of an instant, or no disturbance at all, then, he who sees that,
how does he see it? For the sake of compassion, tell us! It is said to you: It is altogether by viewing that one sees this right viewing.
Without viewing, how would Daśagrīva see the omniscient Buddha, and how (would) now Subhūti the elder
(see) the dharma-kāya? Through his own (?) faith before the Buddha. At that time he saw all the buddhas in full view.
And as he said in the omniscient sutra, in the Prajñāpāramitā: By absence of disturbance, by extinction, in that manner
we see the buddhas in full view. But how does the dharma-kāya stand (there) by absence of disturbance?
All the buddhas of the three times stand (there) in this samādhi, by the help of the production of the samādhi one can see all the lord buddhas.
He to whom it has first appeared thus, only nirvana stands (there) for him all (of it) (?). By the anābhoga career
he has completed the buddha works, he realizes best bodhi. In every instant he turns
the wheel for the sake of beings.
Then how did the five gatis arise, in which(?) one produces forms, sounds, natures, views.
Deign tell us how one may know it! It is said to you: Beings are to be known as just views. There are no real beings.
If there were beings in reality, they would not all be accomodated in the sarvaloka. Form is empty. Always, at all times emptimness. Only
he who (sees?) form and sound similar to ..., is wise there ... views ... going to the five gatis ... will stand(?)
He has cleaned all (in?) his mind. He who recognizes the citta-mātra, altogether (escapes?) from saṃsāra ... Then the kleśa kings and others(?): desire, anger,
folly, (as for) their *counteragents, how must one act? How does one overcome them? It is said to you:
That is to be regarded only as right memory, the nature of equality. Always at all times,
they become nirābhāsa. That (is?) mind. He who first produces various saṃskāras,
at the time of the samādhi he then stands (there) thus like water in a bowl. Then here at the time of illness ... career
is necessary. Teach us now that skill, expediency, how one may know it. It is said to you: The samādhi is to be regarded
as just devoid of vikalpas, pure, undisturbed. That is bodhi, just pure completion, deliverance. How
bodhi pleases ... in ..., do not ask this puzzle, just regard it as extinction,
un-..., unthought memory, in the future do not forget it at all! Being weary, seated, going in a litter,
perform acts! That which arises(?) by help of the production of ..., being awake needs(?) not be awakened. And in the end, he will then
there know everything rightly before his eyes by that anābhoga career. He who has devoted himself to it
however many steps he goes and strides, he goes all of them toward bodhi. When he recognizes the dharmas to be empty, like a dream,
a mirage, at peace, he knows the ... the first bhūmi. Just as he relinquishes life, thereby
he comes to the purified fields, either Sukhāvatī or Abhīrati or among the Tuṣitas, to Maitreya(?). By the help of the production of samādhi
he fulfills the ten bhūmis. And thus by non-obtaining ... dharmas ... he realizes best bodhi.
Those who are bound to the sphere of marks(?), foolish beings, at the time of the teaching of the Law, what(?) skill, expediency (is there) for them?
It is said to them: astīkavādika beings, for them women appear in reality. On account of desire
they go to ... They do not know the meaning of emptiness. For (by?) them medicines are taught to be not good, made of guṇas.

They must remember for the future that they do not have guṇas who shall know that all things are unoriginated. The body (is) ..., filled with impure members, ..., internally ... with breaths. They are 77
thousand, 60 billions. It is very great, which is so very impure, ...
with ... When it is grasped there through desire, that is the root of desire. Through views it is born. When one does not consider it in continuity thus desire it does not arise in the heart.
Like various forms in a dream, of men (and women are not and are stopped by awakening, thus are all the saṃskāras).

recto.line: : mį sta rrį spū rą tcū syau hī ye ā ja ṣąʾ ṇą na ma dryą ną di sta ni ṣṭau vā : dą sau
dī śaʾ vī ra ʾau ṇaṃ dā dra bā ḍa ttai ṣṭaṃ di sau mū hąʾ : ja stau ni ja stą beʾ ysą
ā spā vi nā sau ma nai : beʾ śa mį sta ma hā bū ma prrā pa ttā bau dha są tva
a ra haṃʾ dą pū ñu di śa ra rṇą są tva : tta tti khū są rba cį dī śaʾ jsa a bī rya
vi lą̄ vi de vi na mau a kṣau ba ja sta beʾ ysą ā sta ni ha rbai śa ji stau ną
ja sta beʾ ysą : ra vye pa dī śaʾ jsa na mau ra hną kai tta ja sta beʾ ysą ā sta ną :
haʾ rbai śą ja stau ną ja sta beʾ ysą ñū hū jsa dye dī śaʾ jsa na mau a rmyā
yi ja sta beʾ ysą ā sta ną haʾ rbai śa ja stau ną ja sta beʾ ysą : hau dha rai chau
pa dī śaʾ jsa na mau dau dū beʾ sva ra ja sta beʾ ysą ā sta ną ha rbai śa ja stau na
ja sta beʾ ysą : u skyā ṣṭa dī śaʾ jsa na mau ba di śrī ja sta beʾ ysą ā sta ni
haʾ rbaiʾ śa ja stau na ja sta beʾ ysą : nā ṣṭa dī śaʾ jsa n«†au» mau ve rau ci ja sta
beʾ ysą ā sta na ha rbai śa ja stą beʾ ysą : cu ra tta ttī dī śauʾ vī da śauʾ jsa ʾau
ṇaṃ dā ja sta beʾ ysą ʾī de : tta tta khū di rṇai dą ra ja sta beʾ ysa : śau ttai drai
ja sta beʾ ysą : ciṃ da prra ba ja sta beʾ ysą : nā rā yi ja sta beʾ ysą 1
cu ra tti ttī ma ra myau ña są heʾ lā va de vi : ra hna vyau hąʾ ma ṇḍa la vau ña ra hna
rā śaʾ ra nī ne ysā ra vā rja śī vai ysa bai di ʾau ṇa dai : kṣaʾ sa ka la bau
dha sa tvau nau rau dau jsa paiʾ jsa : na mau da śa bą la ca krra vi rtta ma hā kā ra ṇī tta
śā stā ra śā khya mau na ja sta beʾ ysą ā sta na ja stau na ja sta beʾ ysa ʾī de :
cū ra ttą ttū ṣyąʾ ba vi ña ʾau ṇa de : ma hā da rma rā jaa baʾ ṣai ka prrā pa ttai
ā ryā mai ttrai bau dha są tva pa ḍau ysą̄ ña jsa : baiʾ sta ysā ra bau dha są tvau na rau di
ʾ ī de : tta tta khū ā ryā mai ttrai bau dha są tva : ā ryā va lā ka ttai śva ra bau dha sa tva
ā ryā mi ja śū rī bau dha są tva : ā ryā kṣa tti ga rba bau dha sa tva : ā ryāā kā
śa ga rba bau dha są tva : ā ryā beʾ ṣa ja rā yi bau dha są tva : ā ryā sa ma tta ba
dra bau dha są tva : ā ryā vi jrra pau ṇą bau dha są tva vī bū rai : cū ra tta ttī ha ṣṭū
sa sai śā sta nā bai ba ra prra sā dau na nā vau na rau di ʾī de tta tta khū na di
u pa ni di : gra hąʾ vi da ttą : sū mą pau ña : hū lū ra • bū jsa ja ṣa nī ra ka 2
cū ra tta ttī hau va ni hau va na ja śta ʾī de : tta tta khū śa khī maṃ : śau ka cau
mau ṇyą : hā rrva rai vi drai ṇḍa bū ma dī vya : ka thi dī vya : rā ja dī vya : kū ṣḍi
dī vye ja śta vī bū rai : ʾau da parā ysau da śā pā lā ja stau vī bū rai : ha bai
sta ni ma ra ṣa cū kī tha bī sā na vā ysvą de va ttą pa rvā lā a śte hī ye mi
prra be bā ṣṭā rai : drai kū la hau vi na hau vi na pā ra ṣą dā pā ra ṣṣa dye
«† kū ṣṭą tta saṃ ṣṭā vi ha rbai śa vā vā ṣa • »
hī yvā hī yvā ja sta ba vi nūā nā vi ba va nūā ja stau beʾ ysāṃ ʾī ña kä
dā pvau me be ḍa : kū ṣṭa tta saṃ ṣṭa vi ha rbai śa vā vā ṣṭa na ma drya na pa rya
a vi hā ysye : ma rau va ska ṣṭau ttye dī śaʾ paiʾ ṣka la vī mai sta ma ṇḍą la sthau
pa rī a yī ṣ·ye : ysa rī jai sye jsa pa ṣṭa rda śa dā : va ra ṣṭau hva hva sa rau
vą bai rkha pī la ā ysą na pa rī a yī ṣ·ye : ha rbai śa ttā hī ye hī ye
nū bye hąʾ pa rya ra pā rau tte : ttu ttā dā yī da rma dau na me stye mve śdaʾ jsa ā
ṣaʾ ṇą pa rya ra yu ḍai : cu ma mai sta rrai spū ra tcū syau dra va dya kṣai ttrvā ga rkhyau
vai sthą̄ ryāṃ pū ñaṃ kū śa la mū lyā ha jsau ma jsa tvā rā ha mya ʾī ye : ttu
ṣṭau ttā dra bā ḍau ttai ṣṭa dau ja stau be ysau beʾ śa pī rmā tta u tta tta prra bā
sa da rma dā tta spha ra ṇa vī śai ṣṣa są mū tta ga tta ā sta na pa jsa mą
pū jā ka rma pī rī pa ra ṇau mye 3
bau dha są tvāṃ pau ṇą jñā na saṃ bā ri
de vi ttau pa rvā lą̄ di rma dau ni pī rī pa rą ṇą̄ mye : ttye ttā dā
yī di rma dau na pā rjsai jsą u śa pįʾ ttī śaʾ hū ṣau ma pa ryā vį bī
de : u śaʾ di ttī śauʾ da ṣṭau na ttā dī drą̄ ma vą dya u cī ka są mā hau
na pa ryā vi ra są mā vą jį : cu bū ra jsau meʾ sta rrai spū rą tcū syau a
rrve hva ḍa kha ṣṭa pa rī ye vi rą ṣṭe ttai jsāṃ hā bau dha są tvau u vā ra
tta ra di ra beʾ di ṇe vī au śta vi jsāṃ de : tcau se tcau rai hā ga rkha ā
chā ttai jsāṃ hā bai dā ṣṭą kṣaʾ ṇą ma se rā śaʾ vau nī haʾ ni bye hī de 4
kau mye ją̄ ʾaiʾ ysa a beʾ prrā yi pā rjsa jsa ttu beʾ są prrī yą̄ ga pa sta
ʾ ī ha ṣkau de : ṣeʾ jsā ʾaiʾ są ā vā thyau sī jau me vī tsī ye : pa rye ye śau
ñā tca cā śī ga tsai na hyī
na jsāṃ śrī vī ją tti saṃ grau ma rau di beʾ ysū ñā bve yāṃ ga vūā ga vi va śe
ṣṣa ha mā vį sthau na vī śe ṣa u pa tti vī śe ṣą ja stau beʾ ysau u dā ų
ysdī śā kau pī sau ka lyā ṇą mai ttrau jsa ha gū jsa ha mā ve : hai ysdą
vī jsāṃ the yi pa me styau rraį spū rau rī ysdvī re śau śī śa rā drya nā beʾ ma ñā
ha mā ve : mi sta rrį spū ra tcū syau hī yāṃ cā ttu ttai tcau ṇḍą ka ā staṃ na
ha bā ḍau pa rysāṃ va kṣau na rau ttyāṃ pā ha rbī śvā bā ḍūā śa rā drya nā «† o ne li ne»
baiʾ ma ñā ha mā ve : ga lā na śai lā ā cha na kau sa tvau ā che jsa
pve rā ṣṭa na rau mā ṣṭa ha mā ve : ha spī sa dau jsau kṣauʾ tvā bū mvā
prra saṃ bvā rā śaʾ ha mā ve : ʾau ṣka vī jsā drai na ra nau pā rśaʾ pa jsaṃ
a va ṣṭa ga ca ḍā ve : sa dha rma ttā dā ra va sthu ʾī śā śaʾ pa jsa ma ḍa
śa de ra ysa sa rbī są tvāṃ hau ra ha dā ra pī sa pyā lyai hū ṣą tsī de :
kṣai jai hī ña hī yi vā rā śa vau nī hā grau ha mā ve : na ha mā ha rbībā ḍū ja va gā rą
sa tva vī śauʾ na ra ną ṇī hī sau me vī ra «†» tsī de :
rba ā chai ma na ha mā vai dau ra ha mā vai pa ra

transcription.prose:
: mįsta rrįspūrą tcū syau hīye ājaṣąʾṇą namadryąną dista ni ṣṭau vā : dąsau
dīśaʾ vīra ʾauṇaṃdā drabāḍa ttaiṣṭaṃdi saumūhąʾ : jastauni jastą beʾysą
āspāvi nāsaumanai : beʾśa mįsta mahābūmaprrāpattā baudhasątva
arahaṃʾdą pūñudi śararṇą sątva : tta tti khū sąrbacį dīśaʾ jsa abīrya
vi lą̄videvi namau akṣauba jasta beʾysą āstani harbaiśa jistauną
jasta beʾysą : ravye pa dīśaʾ jsa namau rahnąkaitta jasta beʾysą āstaną :
haʾrbaiśą jastauną jasta beʾysą ñūhūjsadye dīśaʾ jsa namau armyā-
yi jasta beʾysą āstaną haʾrbaiśa jastauną jasta beʾysą : haudha raichau
pa dīśaʾ jsa namau daudūbeʾsvara jasta beʾysą āstaną harbaiśa jastauna
jasta beʾysą : uskyāṣṭa dīśaʾ jsa namau badiśrī jasta beʾysą āstani
haʾrbaiʾśa jastauna jasta beʾysą : nāṣṭa dīśaʾ jsa n«†au»mau verauci jasta
beʾysą āstana harbaiśa jastą beʾysą : cu ra tta ttī dīśauʾ vīdaśauʾ jsa ʾau-
ṇaṃdā jasta beʾysą ʾīde : tta tta khū dirṇaidąra jasta beʾysa : śauttaidrai
jasta beʾysą : ciṃdaprraba jasta beʾysą : nārāyi jasta beʾysą 1
cu ra tti ttī mara myauña sąheʾ lāvadevi : rahnavyauhąʾmaṇḍala vauña rahna-
rāśaʾ ranīne ysāra-vārja śī vaiysa baidi ʾauṇadai : kṣaʾsa kala bau-
dhasatvaunau raudau jsa paiʾjsa : namau daśabąla-cakrravirtta mahākāraṇītta
śāstāra śākhyamauna jasta beʾysą āstana jastauna jasta beʾysa ʾīde :
cū ra ttą ttūṣyąʾ baviña ʾauṇade : mahādarmarāja-abaʾṣaikaprrāpattai
āryā-maittrai baudhasątva paḍauysą̄ña jsa : baiʾsta ysāra baudhasątvauna raudi
ʾīde : tta tta khū āryā-maittrai baudhasątva : āryāvalākattaiśvara baudhasatva
āryā-mijaśūrī baudhasątva : āryā-kṣattigarba baudhasatva : āryā-ākā-
śagarba baudhasątva : āryā-beʾṣajarāyi baudhasątva : āryā-samattaba-
dra baudhasątva : āryā-vijrrapauṇą baudhasątva vī būrai : cū ra tta ttī haṣṭū-
sa sai śāstanābaibaraprrasādauna nāvauna raudi ʾīde tta tta khū nadi
upanidi : grahąʾvidattą : sūmąpauña : hūlūra • būjsaja ṣanīraka 2
cū ra tta ttī hauvani hauvana jaśta ʾīde : tta tta khū śakhīmaṃ : śaukacau-
mauṇyą : hārrva raivi draiṇḍa būma-dīvya : kathi-dīvya : rāja-dīvya : kūṣḍi-
dīvye jaśta vī būrai : ʾauda pa(dā)-rāysau daśāpālā jastau vī būrai : habai-
stani mara ṣacū kītha bīsā navāysvą devattą parvālā aśte hīye mi
prrabebā ṣṭārai : drai kūla hauvina hauvina pāraṣądā pāraṣṣadye
«†kū ṣṭą tta saṃ ṣṭāvi harbaiśa vā vāṣa • »
hīyvā hīyvā jasta-bavinūā nāvi-bavanūā jastau beʾysāṃ ʾīñakä
dā pvaume beḍa : kūṣṭa tta saṃ ṣṭavi harbaiśa-v-ā vāṣṭa namadryana parya
avihāysye : marau vaska ṣṭau ttye dīśaʾ paiʾṣkala vī maista maṇḍąla-sthau
parī ayīṣ(ṭ)ye : ysarījai sye jsa paṣṭarda śadā : vara ṣṭau hva hva sarau-
vą bairkha pīla āysąna parī ayīṣ(ṭ)ye : harbaiśa ttā hīye hīye
nū byehąʾ paryara pārautte : ttu ttā dāyī darmadauna mestye mveśdaʾ jsa ā-
ṣaʾṇą paryara yuḍai : cu ma maista rraispūra tcū syau dra-vadya kṣaittrvā garkhyau
vaisthą̄ryāṃ pūñaṃ kūśalamūlyā hajsauma jsa tvārā hamya ʾīye : ttu
ṣṭau ttā dra-bāḍau ttaiṣṭadau jastau beysau beʾśa pīrmātta u tta tta prrabā-
sadarmadāttaspharaṇavīśaiṣṣasąmūttagatta āstana pajsamą
pūjākarma pīrī paraṇaumye 3
baudhasątvāṃ pauṇą jñāna saṃbāri
devittau parvālą̄ dirmadauni pīrī parąṇą̄mye : ttye ttā dā-
yī dirmadauna pārjsai jsą uśa pįʾ ttīśaʾ hūṣauma paryāvį bī-
de : uśaʾdi ttīśauʾda ṣṭauna ttā dīdrą̄ma-vądya u cīka sąmāhau-
na paryāvi ra sąmāvąjį : cu būra jsau meʾsta rraispūrą tcū syau a-
rrve hvaḍa khaṣṭa parīye virąṣṭe ttai jsāṃ hā baudhasątvau uvāra
ttaradira beʾdi ṇe vī auśta vijsāṃde : tcause tcaurai hā garkha ā-
chā ttai jsāṃ hā baidāṣṭą kṣaʾṇą-mase rāśaʾ vaunīhaʾ ni byehīde 4
kaumye ją̄ ʾaiʾysa abeʾprrāyi pārjsa jsa ttu beʾsą prrīyą̄ga pasta
ʾī haṣkaude : ṣeʾ jsā ʾaiʾsą āvā thyau sījaume vī tsīye : parye ye śau
ñā tcacā śīga tsai na hyī
na jsāṃ śrī vījątti saṃgrauma raudi beʾysūñā bveyāṃ gavūā gavivaśe-
ṣṣa hamāvį sthaunavīśeṣa upattivīśeṣą jastau beʾysau u dā ų-
ysdīśākau pīsau kalyāṇąmaittrau jsa hagūjsa hamāve : haiysdą
vī jsāṃ theyi pa mestyau rraįspūrau rīysdvīre śau śī śarādryanā beʾmañā
hamāve : mista rrįspūra tcū syau hīyāṃ cāttuttai tcauṇḍąka āstaṃna
habāḍau parysāṃ vakṣaunarau ttyāṃ pā harbīśvā bāḍūā śarādryanā «†one line»
baiʾmañā hamāve : galānaśailā āchanakau satvau āche jsa
pverāṣṭa naraumāṣṭa hamāve : haspīsadau jsau kṣauʾtvā būmvā
prrasaṃbvā rāśaʾ hamāve : ʾauṣka vī jsā draina ranau pārśaʾ pajsaṃ
avaṣṭa ga caḍāve : sadharma ttā dāra vasthu ʾī śāśaʾ pajsamaḍa
śade raysa sarbī sątvāṃ haura hadāra pīsa pyālyai hūṣą tsīde :
kṣaijai hīña hīyi vā rāśa vaunīhā grau hamāve : na hamā harbī(śa) bāḍū ja va gārą
satva vīśauʾna ranąṇī hīsaume vīra «† » tsīde :
rba āchai ma na hamāvai daura hamāvai para

translation.line: The imploration, invitation of the great Prince Tcū Syau ...
We take refuge with the lords of lord buddhas in the ten directions, of the three times, standing in full view, all the great bodhisattvas and arhats who have reached the great earth,
meritorious, well-doing beings. Thus, in the eastern direction, in the Abhīrati
world sphere, hail to the lord buddha Akṣobhya and all the other
lords of lord buddhas. In the southern direction, hail to the lord buddha Ratnaketu and
all the other lords of lord buddhas. In the western direction hail to the lord buddha Amitāyu
and all the other lords of lord buddhas. In the direction of the Seven Sages
hail to the lord buddha Dundubhisvara and all the other
lords of lord buddhas. In the upward direction, hail to the lord buddha Bhadraśrī and
all the other lords of lord buddhas. In the downward direction, hail to the lord buddha Vairocana
and all the other lords of lord buddhas,— and whatever lord buddhas there are sitting in the ten directions and subdirections,
for instance, the lord buddha Dirṇaidąra, the lord buddha Śāntendriya,
the lord buddha Candraprabha, the lord buddha Narāyaṇa. 1.
And whatever lords of lord buddhas are here in the middle of the world sphere Sahā, in the temple of the Ratnavyūhamaṇḍala,
in the Ratnarāśi(?), sitting on a bejeweled, thousand-petaled, white lotus, surrounded by 16 trillion bodhisattva kings, hail to the daśa-bala-cakravartin mahākāruṇika(?)
the teacher Śākyamuni and the other lord buddhas.

And whatever 20 thousand bodhisattva kings there are sitting in the dwelling of the Tuṣitas, mahā-rāja-abhiṣeka-prāpta, led by the bodhisattva Āryā-Maitreya: the bodhisattva Āryā-Maitreya, and the others: the bodhisattva Āryāvalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva Āryā-Mañjuśrī, the bodhisattva Āryā-Kṣitigarbha, the bodhisattva Āryā-Ākāśagarbha, the bodhisattva Āryā-Bhaiṣajyarāja, the bodhisattva Āryā-Samantabhadra, to the bodhisattva Āryā-Vajrapāṇi. And whatever eighty
hundred(?) śāstanābaibaraprrasāda nāga kings there are, such as Nada,
Upanada, Grahavidatta, Sūmapuṇya, Hulura, Bujsajsa, Ṣanīraka. 2.
And whatever very powerful goddesses there are, such as Śakhīmaṃ, Śaukacaumauṇya,
Hāritī ..., Dṛḍhā Deity of Earth, the Deity of the City, the Deity of Kings,
to the goddess Deity of the Palace. Finally, the gods protecting the directions. Altogether,
the protector deities inhabitants of the city of Shazhou, whose
images are here. For the three billions of very powerful lord buddhas in the various dwellings of gods and dwellings of nāgas belonging to the various asssemblies (of monks).
At the time of the hearing of the Law, wherever you may be, deign to cherish all our invitations!
Deign bless for us here the great maṇḍala-sthāna in the sections of that place!
The earth covered by golden sand, there deign to bless the individual lions, *wolves, elephants, seats!
Deign enter the various ... of them all! Deign make worthy through (your) great compassion this their dharma-dāna of the Law!
Whatever may have become here for the great Prince Tcū Syau conveyance(?) into the three fields through (his) accumulation of heavy, extended merits and roots of goodness,

that very foremost worship and acts of worship for the standing lord buddhas of the three times as well as the (acts of worship) such as prabhāsadharma-dhātu-spharaṇa-viśeṣa-samudgata, (that) deign to ripen (for him)! 3. The pāṇi(?)-jñāna-sambhāra of the bodhisattvas,
the dharma-dāna of the protecting deities may he deign to ripen (for him)!
He shall deign to find for him(?) by support(?) on their dharma-dāna power, strength, splendor, and growth!
And being powerful and strong he shall deign to produce (samāpad) for them (their?) so many kinds of and ... samādhis.
As many medicines, foods, and drinks the great Prince Tcū Syau may deign to prepare, (all) those ... on the exalted bodies of the bodhisattvas.
The forty-four severe illnesses will in an instant no longer obtain control over him. 4.
Supported on whatever ... abhiprāya he may have deigned perform, may this ... prayoga, this ... quickly go to success.
... may he have a gati-viśeṣa in the gatis of the buddha ... of King Śrī Vijita Saṃgrāma, a sthāna-viśeṣa, a upatti-viśeṣa!
May he have a meeting with the lord buddhas and the teachers of the Law, and (his) kalyāṇa-mitras!
May there immediately, O Theyi Pa, O great princes and princesses, be one ... of ... fortunes!
May there be, for the great Prince Tcū Syau’s ... and the other ..., for them at all times ... fortunes!
May there be for sickened beings full of illnesses separation and going away from the illnesses.
May he always, go to a gati *unattached (to the kleśas?) in the worship and service of the Three Jewels! ...

comments.comment: On the back of Chinese Saddharmapuṇḍarīka-sūtra. The “Invocation of Prince Tcū-Syau.” Lines 2-35 tr. Bailey, 1942, pp. 889, 891. Guide2 [18.32]. Lines 1-11 on PLATE 8a.
On the back of long (820x25 cm) scroll containing Chinese Mahāparinirvāṇa-sūtra. Lines 1-131 homage to the buddhas, lines 132-228 confession text.

bī śī da gya sta
baʾ ysa hi mā re haṃ baʾ ci jsa tci hauʾ si kū la pī rma

ną̄ ma pyū ṣḍe siʾ dra yvā a vā yvā paṃ da ba sta ni ni na rya

na mau u tta ri prri dī pi gya stä
baʾ ysä na ma suṃ cvai ną̄ ma hvą̄ ñe ni ni ga rkhyāṃ ā chāṃ jsi

lai spye hī ya bu śi ni rą̄ me ni ni kū ṭhiṃ gvā ysai ye

sa rbaṃ di di śiʾ jsa

sti baʾ ysä na ma suṃ ną̄ da
na mau ā ryā mai ttrai bau dha

ma suṃ na mau ā ryā vi lau kyi tte śva ri bau di sa tvi
na ma suṃ : || na mau ā ryā ma ju śrī bau dha sa tvä na
ma suṃ na mau ā ryā kṣi tta ga rbhi bau dha sa tva na ma suṃ
na mau ā ryā bhai ṣa jya rā ji bau dha sa tvi na ma suṃ
na mau ā ryā sa maṃ tta bha dri bau di sa tvi na ma suṃ

na mau di śą di śą̄ nāṃ • tti ṣṭhaṃ dą̄ nāṃ • bau dhą̄ nāṃ •

ka rmā kṣīʾ yi bhū je svā hā ||

translation.line: Welfare! Hail! The twelve billions of lord buddhas called Ratnottama,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighteen billions of
lord buddhas called Ratnāvabhāsa, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The twenty billions of lord buddhas called Śikhin,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred lord buddhas
called Kanakamuni, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The three hundred billions of lord buddhas called Avabhāsaśrī, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The ninety-five billions of lord buddhas called Puṣya,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twelve billions of lord buddhas
called Kauṭinya, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The two thousand billions of lord
buddhas called Kauṭinya, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The six hundred billions of lord buddhas called Vimalaprabha,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight thousands of lord
called Indradhvaja, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ninety-five billions of
lord buddhas called Indradhvaja, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The eight hundred lord buddhas called Suprabhāsa, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The ninety billions of lord buddhas called Krakasunda, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eighty billions of lord buddhas called Candrasūryapradīpa,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The five thousand
lord buddhas called Pradyota, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The five hundred lord buddhas called Pratāpana, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eight thousand lord buddhas called Nāga,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The five thousand lord buddhas
called Āditya, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred
thousand lord buddhas called Śamatha, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eight thousand lord buddhas called Sālarāja,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twenty billions of lord buddhas
called Kāśyapa, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ninety-five billions of
lord buddhas called Śākyamuni, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The twelve billions of lord buddhas called Vipaśyin, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eighty billions of lord buddhas called Svabhāvadharmottara,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ten thousand
lord buddhas called Prasannavadana-utpalagandhakūṭa, (34) I do homage to them all. Reverence!

(Whatever) buddhas there may be everywhere, altogether forty billions, eighteen lakhs, seventeen thousand, eight-hundred in front, he who hears their names, for him the path to the three apāyas is blocked, and he will not go to a hell, nor among ghosts or animals. He who learns them (and) brings them with ..., he can no more be turned away from bodhi. No doubt should be entertained there.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Uttarapradīpa! He who speaks his name will no more be afflicted by severe illnesses.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Jotisaumyagandhāvabhāsaśrī! He who speaks his name will no more become a woman until bodhi.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Jñānolka! He who speaks his name will no more take birth in the great hell Avīcī.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Asaṅgarāja! He who speaks his name will no more fall into misfortunes, contentions, or prisons.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Anantayaśa! He who speaks his name will be freed from all sins.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Meru! He who speaks his name will not obtain birth in a hell.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Mahāmeru! He who speaks his name will not obtain birth among ghosts.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Amitameru! He who speaks his name will not obtain birth among animals.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Akṣobhya! He who speaks his name ... will *distribute unobstructed food and drink to the bhikṣusaṅghas.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Ratnaketu! He who speaks his name, whatever sins he has accumulated for eighty billions of eons, they will all be destroyed for him.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Dundubhisvara! He who speaks his name will have as beautiful a voice as (that which is produced) by the striking of the buddha drum.

Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Ratna-kusuma-guṇa-sāgara-vaiḍūrya-kanaka-giri-svarṇa-kāñcana-prabhāsa-śrī! He who speaks his name he will have success with all his crops, he will be wealthy, blessed.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Sudarśana! He who speaks his name, acts and sins (committed) for eons will be destroyed for him. He will be good-looking, graceful.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Vairocana! He who speaks his name will obtain the body of the Law.

Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Gandhottama! He who speaks his name, throughout his births the perfume of the pure lotus flower will come out of his mouth. No more will he be born among the leprous.
Hail to the tathāgata Aparimita-guṇa-ratna-śrī-vyūha-teja-rāja-kalpa!
Hail to the tathāgata Sarvadharma-pratibhāsa-śrī!
Hail to the tathāgata Bahu-vividha-tejo-rājā-śrī-nirbhāso!
Hail to the tathāgata Asaṃkhyeya-kalpa-koṭi-samudānīta-buddho!
Hail to the tathāgata Śubha-kanaka-nirvāda-vyūha-nirbhāso!
Hail to the tathāgata Sarvadharma-naya-vikurvita-tejo!
Hail to the tathāgata Guṇa-saṃkusamito!
Hail to the tathāgata Padmottara-śrī!
Hail to the tathāgata Padma-hasto!
Hail! to the lord buddha Sūrya-maṇḍala-prabhāsa-śrī I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Sarva-uttama-paripūrṇa-lakṣaṇa-kāya-gātra I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Sarva-samādhi-rutta-vikrama I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Ratna-kusuma-samantā-anantāvabhāsa-śrī I do homage! (Reverence!)
Hail! to the lord buddha Anuttara-padma-vikrama I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Ratna-padma-vikrama I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Ratna-garbha I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Ratna-śikha I do homage! Reverence!
(Hail!) to the lord buddha Ratnottama I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Sarva-ratna-pratimaṇḍita-rūpa-dhārī I do homage! Reverence!

He who may hear the names of these lord buddhas, orders them to be written, or speaks (them) will obtain the confession of sins (even) in the ananta-naryas. And so many beings *bound in the next world will escape from them as there are grits and sands in the river Ganges. No doubt should be entertained there. ... I do homage to the 1005 bhadrakalpika lord buddhas, from hail! the lord buddha Krakasunda to the Lord Buddha Rūja(?). Reverence! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Mahā-śākyamuni! Reverence!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Dīpaṃkara! Reverence!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Rāja-grāmaka! Reverence!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Tcauvabąnī! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Ditkabąnī! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Kaulyāna!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha dwelling in Dviyaśāya(?)!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Kṣemaṃkara!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha of the hauymas(?)! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha of the maʾysakas(?)!
In the eastern direction I do homage to the lord buddha
Akṣobhya. Reverence! In the southern direction,
hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Ratnaketu. In the western
direction, hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Amitāyu.
In the northern direction, hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Dundubhisvara.
In the first subdirection I do homage to the lord buddha Dharaṇiṃdhara.
In the second subdirection I do homage the lord buddha Candraprabha together with
his assembly. In the third subdirection
I do homage to the lord buddha Nārāyaṇa. Reverence! In the fourth subdirection
I do homage the lord buddha Śāntendriya. Reverence! In the upward direction
I do homage to the lord buddha Bhadraśrī. In the downward direction
I do homage to the lord buddha Vairocana. Reverence! Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Maitreya!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Ākāśagarbha!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryāvalokiteśvara! Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Mañjuśrī!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Bhaiṣajyarāja!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Samantabhadra!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Vajrapāṇi!
(Skt.:) Hail to the laukyidārtha buddha bhagavāns standing in the ten directions. Tad-yathā ...

comments.comment: Homage to the buddhas (“namo text”). Cf. Guide2 [18.6] (under Bhadrakalpika-sūtra). Cf. Or.8210/S. 2471, IOL Khot S. 46. Lines 1-10 on PLATE 8b.
Confession text also found in Ch.00277 (IOL Khot S. 18) and Ch.xlvi.0013a (IOL Khot 56/1). Synop-tic text and translation in Emmerick, 1977a. Guide2 [18.34].
